title: Things you need to do if you’re diagnosed with pre-diabetes - The Indian Express
summary:
Things You Need to Do If You’re Diagnosed with Pre-Diabetes

Publication Date: Not specified

Source: The Indian Express

Prediabetes is a manageable illness that can be controlled with lifestyle modifications such as a nutrient-dense diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean meats, and healthy fats, as well as avoiding sugary and processed foods.

  • Engage in strength training and 150–180 minutes of moderate exercise per week to enhance insulin sensitivity.
  • Focus on weight management, aiming to lose 5–7% of body weight for better insulin sensitivity.
  • Monitor blood glucose levels regularly to make informed dietary and lifestyle choices.
  • Ensure 7 to 8 hours of sleep each night and practice stress-reduction techniques.
  • Adopt a holistic approach to prevent type 2 diabetes and reduce the risk of heart disease.
“Preventing the development of type 2 diabetes and lowering the risk of associated disorders like heart disease can be achieved by taking proactive measures.”

By implementing small, sustainable lifestyle changes, individuals can improve both short-term and long-term health outcomes.
newTitle: Things You Need to Do If You’re Diagnosed with Pre-Diabetes

title: Causes of dementia: Genetics, high blood pressure, diabetes, obesity are high risk factor - Moneycontrol
summary:
Understanding the Causes of Dementia: Key Risks and Preventive Measures

Publication Date: July 30, 2024
Source: Moneycontrol

Dementia is a progressive condition that affects memory, concentration, and judgment, significantly impacting daily life. While aging plays a major role, high blood pressure, diabetes, obesity, and genetic factors are critical contributors.

  • A recent study indicates that 42% of Americans over 55 are at risk of dementia, a significant rise from previous estimates.
  • Women have a higher risk of 48% compared to men's 35%, largely due to longer lifespans.
  • The expected number of new dementia cases in the U.S. is half a million this year, potentially reaching one million annually by 2060.
“Dementia is becoming a critical public health issue.”

In conclusion, understanding the risk factors and preventive measures is essential in combating the rise of dementia cases, emphasizing the need for health awareness and lifestyle changes.
newTitle: Understanding the Causes of Dementia: Key Risks and Preventive Measures

title: 10 health benefits of ajwain: Weight loss, digestion, more - Moneycontrol
summary:
10 Health Benefits of Ajwain: Weight Loss, Digestion, and More

Date: January 14, 2025 Source: Moneycontrol

Ajwain, also known as carom seeds, offers numerous health benefits, particularly in aiding digestion and promoting weight loss.

  • Aids digestion by stimulating digestive enzymes.
  • Relieves gas buildup and bloating.
  • Soothes abdominal cramps and discomfort.
  • Reduces congestion and aids respiratory symptoms.
  • Supports weight loss by boosting metabolism.
  • Improves appetite and gut health.
  • Offers relief from acidity and heartburn.
  • Provides natural relief from joint pain linked to arthritis.
  • Regulates blood sugar levels, helpful for diabetes.
"Ajwain's anti-inflammatory properties reduce joint pain and swelling associated with arthritis."

Incorporating ajwain into your diet can enhance digestive health and provide various benefits beyond just digestion.

title: 10 fibre-packed foods for a strong immune system, healthy gut - Moneycontrol
summary:
10 Fibre-Packed Foods for a Strong Immune System and Healthy Gut

Published on: January 14, 2025 | Source: Moneycontrol

This article discusses ten foods that are high in fiber and their contributions to a stronger immune system and improved gut health.

  • Lentils: Rich in protein, fiber, and iron; supports heart health and digestion.
  • Chickpeas: High in protein, fiber, and healthy fats; regulates blood sugar and promotes muscle growth.
  • Apples: Great source of fiber and vitamin C; boosts immunity and supports digestion.
  • Sweet Potatoes: Contain antioxidants and fiber; support vision and immune function.
  • Broccoli: Loaded with vitamins and minerals; offers anti-inflammatory benefits.
  • Flaxseeds: Rich in omega-3 fatty acids and fiber; reduce inflammation and support heart health.
  • Berries: High in antioxidants; protect against chronic disease and boost immunity.
  • Whole Grains: Packed with fiber and B vitamins; improve digestion and regulate blood sugar.
  • Beans: Source of plant-based protein and fiber; improve digestion and heart health.
newTitle: 10 Fibre-Packed Foods for a Strong Immune System and Healthy Gut

Innovations in HIV Care for Women Worldwide - Medscape
summary:
Innovations in HIV Care for Women Worldwide

Publication Date: October 2023

Source: Medscape

This article discusses the alarming rise of HIV infections among women, particularly young cisgender women and those over 50. It highlights the barriers to accessing preventive measures and the innovative approaches being developed to improve care and adherence.

Key Points:

  • 4000 young cisgender women aged 15-24 contract HIV globally each week.
  • Women aged 50+ experiencing an increase in HIV infections.
  • Awareness and access to HIV preventive measures like PrEP and PEP are severely limited.
  • Misperceptions about personal risk and lack of healthcare provider guidance contribute to low adoption of prevention methods.
  • Innovative prophylactic options, including long-acting injectables and vaginal rings, show promise.
“Despite barriers to PrEP and PEP implementation among women, success stories from around the world show that these challenges can be overcome.”

In conclusion, integrating comprehensive HIV prevention strategies into healthcare systems can significantly improve outcomes for women globally.
newTitle: Innovations in HIV Care for Women Worldwide

Morning coffee cuts health risks, but all-day sipping doesn’t - News-Medical.Net
summary:
Morning Coffee Cuts Health Risks, But All-Day Sipping Doesn’t

Date: January 13, 2025 | Source: News-Medical

Drinking coffee at the right time of day could hold the key to a longer, healthier life—discover how your morning brew may protect your heart and boost longevity!

  • A study published in the European Heart Journal analyzed the effects of coffee drinking timing on mortality.
  • More than 42,000 US adults participated in the study.
  • Morning coffee drinkers showed lower risks of cardiovascular disease (CVD) specific mortality compared to all-day coffee drinkers.
  • The study emphasized that moderate morning coffee consumption might reduce mortality risk.
  • Key findings suggest circadian disruption from late coffee consumption could negatively impact health.

“Our findings highlight the importance of considering drinking timing in the association between the amounts of coffee intake and health outcomes.”

Overall, this study identifies the timing of coffee consumption as a potentially significant factor affecting health outcomes, emphasizing the benefits of restricting coffee intake to morning hours.
newTitle: Morning Coffee Reduces Health Risks, But All-Day Drinking May Not

title: Winter Cold and Smoking Calls for Heightened Risks of Heart Diseases - News18
summary:
Winter Cold and Smoking Calls for Heightened Risks of Heart Diseases

Date: January 14, 2025 Source: News18

The article discusses how the winter season and smoking habits significantly increase the risk of heart diseases, particularly for those with pre-existing conditions. Seasonal changes compel people to exercise less and can exacerbate cardiovascular issues.

  • Research shows a strong link between winter and heart attacks.
  • Cold conditions put extra strain on the heart, requiring more oxygen.
  • Smoking damages blood vessels and increases vulnerability to heart attacks.
  • Those with hypertension are particularly at risk for cold-induced issues.
  • Tobacco cessation therapy is crucial for reducing heart disease risk.
  • Nicotine Replacement Therapy (NRT) helps quit smoking, leading to improved heart health.
“Nicotine Replacement Therapy (NRT) is a proven method to help people quit smoking, which can have a significant positive impact on heart health.” - Dr. Sagar Verma

In conclusion, addressing smoking habits and taking preventive measures during the cold season can help reduce the risks of heart disease effectively.
newTitle: Winter Cold and Smoking Increase Heart Disease Risks

How serious is bird flu? - The Hub at Johns Hopkins
summary:
How Serious is Bird Flu?

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

As the first bird flu death in the U.S. raises alarm, experts provide insights into the risks and necessary precautions regarding the H5N1 virus.

Key Points

  • A Louisiana resident became the first U.S. human death from H5N1, contracted from exposure to wild birds and chickens.
  • Experts stress that the risk to the general public remains low, but the virus’s adaptability and mutation potential are concerning.
  • Preventative measures include avoiding raw dairy and meat products, and practices to protect pets and backyard poultry.
"At this point, we've seen no evidence of human-to-human transmission..." - Meghan Davis

The emergence of H5N1 in new species beyond birds, including dairy cows and other mammals, complicates tracking and management. Continued monitoring and education are essential to prevent outbreaks.
newTitle: Understanding the Risks of Bird Flu in the U.S.

title: Risks of taking vitamin D in the wrong way and how to take it safely - The Times of India
summary:
Risks of Taking Vitamin D in the Wrong Way and How to Take It Safely

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: Times of India

Vitamin D, known as the 'sunshine vitamin', is crucial for bone health and immune function. However, improper intake can lead to severe health complications.

  • Vitamin D toxicity can occur from excessive intake, leading to symptoms like nausea and kidney damage.
  • Improper vitamin D use may cause calcium imbalances, resulting in kidney stones and cardiovascular issues.
  • Gastrointestinal problems can arise from incorrect dosages, especially when taken on an empty stomach.
  • Vitamin D can interact with certain medications, potentially reducing their effectiveness.
  • Consulting with a healthcare provider before starting supplementation is essential.
  • Prior testing is recommended to determine appropriate supplementation levels.
  • Vitamin D should be taken with meals containing healthy fats for better absorption.
“Avoid excessive doses unless prescribed by a healthcare provider.”

In conclusion, understanding how to take vitamin D safely is key to maximizing its health benefits while minimizing risks.
newTitle: Risks of Taking Vitamin D in the Wrong Way and How to Take It Safely

title: Bioengineers found breakthrough in building smart cells, potential to detect autoimmune disease: Study - ETHealthWorld
summary:
Bioengineers found breakthrough in building smart cells, potential to detect autoimmune disease: Study

Date: January 14, 2025
Source: ANI

Rice University bioengineers have developed a new construction kit for building custom sense-and-respond circuits in human cells. This research signifies a major breakthrough in synthetic biology that could provide new therapies for complex conditions like autoimmune diseases and cancer.

  • The new construction kit allows for creating smart cells that can detect specific cellular signals.
  • This innovation could lead to immediate releases of customizable treatments in response to detected signs of diseases.
  • The research was published in the journal Science.
"Imagine tiny processors inside cells made of proteins that can 'decide' how to respond to specific signals like inflammation or tumor growth markers," said Xiaoyu Yang, lead author of the study.

This groundbreaking work suggests a shift in synthetic biology and cellular therapies, offering hope for more advanced treatments for serious health conditions.
newTitle: Breakthrough in Building Smart Cells to Detect Autoimmune Diseases

title: Watching reels at night? Late-night social media use may cause hypertension, new study suggests - The Times of India
summary:
Watching reels at night? Late-night social media use may cause hypertension, new study suggests

Date: October 2023

Source: BMC

A recent study has revealed a concerning correlation between late-night screen time spent on short videos and the risk of developing hypertension among young and middle-aged adults.

  • The study involved 4,318 Chinese participants focusing on screen time before bed.
  • More hours spent watching short videos at night increased the risk of hypertension.
  • Dr. Deepak Krishnamurthy emphasized the dangers of distractions from short video addiction.
  • Recommendations include limiting late-night screen time to improve sleep hygiene and prevent hypertension.
"Short video addiction does not only present a significant distraction but also helps in raising blood pressure." - Dr. Deepak Krishnamurthy

The findings underscore the need for individuals, especially the youth, to adopt healthier screen habits and lifestyles to mitigate the risk of hypertension.
newTitle: Late-Night Social Media Use Linked to Hypertension in New Study

title: Another child tests positive for HMPV in Puducherry, 3 cases reported so far - ETHealthWorld
summary:
Another child tests positive for HMPV in Puducherry, 3 cases reported so far

Date: January 14, 2025

Source: PTI

Puducherry has reported its third case of Human metapneumovirus (HMPV) as another child tested positive. The Director of Medical Services stated that the latest case had symptoms of fever and cough and was admitted to JIPMER on January 10. Fortunately, the child is recovering well.

  • Third reported case of HMPV in Puducherry.
  • Previous cases involved children aged three and five.
  • Puducherry government is enhancing hospital infrastructure for better management.
“The child was recovering well,” - Director of Medical Services V Ravichandran.

This emergence of HMPV cases in Puducherry is concerning, and the administration is taking necessary steps to manage the situation.
newTitle: Another child tests positive for HMPV in Puducherry, 3 cases reported so far

Beat the Blues with your plate: Can a fibre-rich diet fight depression? - The Hindu
summary:
Beat the Blues with Your Plate: Can a Fibre-Rich Diet Fight Depression?

Published on: January 14, 2025 Source: Unknown

Research indicates that a fibre-rich diet can significantly reduce the risk of depression, with greater benefits observed in adolescents. This article explores the connections between diet, especially fibre intake, and mental health, particularly in the context of rising depression rates in India.

  • A high-fibre diet is associated with lower odds of depression, with a 57% reduction in risk for adolescents.
  • Research published in Nutritional Neuroscience showcases findings from 18 studies on fibre intake and mental health.
  • Traditional Indian diets rich in fibre are essential in supporting mental well-being.
  • Modern dietary shifts toward processed foods may exacerbate mental health issues.
“Taking care of your mind starts with taking care of your body.” - Dr. Hemant Bhargav

In conclusion, prioritizing a fibre-rich and nutrient-dense diet may be pivotal in managing and preventing depression.
newTitle: Beat the Blues with Your Plate: Can a Fibre-Rich Diet Fight Depression?

title: Sierra Leone declares emergency after confirming 2nd mpox case in 4 days - The Washington Post
summary:
Sierra Leone Declares Emergency After Second Mpox Case in Four Days

Date: Monday, Source: AP News

DAKAR, Senegal — Sierra Leone declared a state of emergency Monday after the country reported its second case of mpox in less than four days, health authorities said.

  • Neither case had known recent contact with infected animals or sick individuals.
  • The first case involved recent travel limited to the airport town of Lungi.
  • Both patients are receiving treatment at a hospital in the capital, Freetown.
No known contact with infected animals or sick individuals has been reported.

The rapid emergence of mpox cases in Sierra Leone has raised health concerns and prompted immediate action from authorities.
newTitle: Sierra Leone Declares Emergency After Second Mpox Case in Four Days

title: ‘Even with a broken foot, I was…’: How Chhavi Mittal prioritised health and conquered challenges post-cancer - The Indian Express
summary:
‘Even with a broken foot, I was…’: How Chhavi Mittal prioritised health and conquered challenges post-cancer

Publication Date: 2024

Source: Indian Express

Chhavi Mittal’s commitment to her health after battling cancer is a testament to her strength and determination, even as she faced challenges like foot fractures in 2024.

  • Chhavi shared her experiences on Instagram, emphasizing her focus on health and fitness post-cancer.
  • Despite experiencing multiple fractures, she continued to pursue physical activity and personal records.
  • Dr. Srinath highlights the importance of weight training for bone health and reducing fracture risks.
  • Precautionary measures are crucial when engaging in intense physical activities, especially after cancer recovery.
  • Structured goal setting and gradual progress in exercises help prevent injury and burnout.
“Setting SMART goals ensures realistic progress, such as increasing squat strength by 10% in eight weeks.” - Dr. Srinath

This journey underscores the significance of prioritizing health, gradual recovery, and the role of mental and physical practices in overcoming adversity.
newTitle: Chhavi Mittal's Inspiring Journey of Health and Resilience Post-Cancer

Foods to eat and to avoid for better skin: Your diet to deal with acne, wrinkles or dryness - CNA
summary:
Foods to Eat and Avoid for Better Skin: Your Diet to Deal with Acne, Wrinkles or Dryness

Publication Date: December 20, 2024

Source: Channel News Asia

This article explores the connection between diet and skin health, emphasizing how certain foods can exacerbate skin issues like acne, dryness, and signs of aging. Dermatologists provide insights on what to eat and what to avoid for healthier skin.

  • Acne: Avoid dairy and whey protein.
  • Signs of aging: Avoid white sugar and high glycemic index foods.
  • Dermatitis: Avoid spicy foods, hot drinks, and alcohol.
  • Dryness and dehydration: Avoid diuretic foods and high sodium foods.
“Eating a diet rich in antioxidants can help the skin recover from years of sun damage.” – Dr. Lynn Chiam

The article concludes with the encouragement to eat more foods that are good for the skin, such as antioxidants, omega-3 fatty acids, probiotics, and vitamins.
newTitle: Foods to Eat and Avoid for Healthy Skin
